li.p: We define the logarithmic function, g(x) = \log_b x, which takes the log base b of its input values. The log function g(x) = \log_b x is the inverse of the exponential function f (x) = b^x.
A logarithmic equation is one in which the variable appears inside of a logarithm. We can solve logarithmic equations by converting to exponential form.
Can the output of the function y = \log_b x be negative?
Francine says that \log_2 \dfrac{1}{x}= -\log_2 x. Is she correct? Why or why not?

Why is the following attempt to solve the equation incorrect?
\bluetext{Solve:}\hphantom{blank}\log x + \log(x + 1) \amp= 2
x + x + 1 \amp= 10^2
